Abstract. With the development of The Times, gender education of students has been paid more and more attention. Good gender education also helps students to view themselves and treat others more perfectly. In order to improve the gender education consciousness of teachers and students in a primary school in Henan Province and promote the development of gender education in Henan Province, the author used an offline questionnaire survey and literature review to investigate the cognition of fifth and sixth-grade primary school students on gender stereotypes. From four points of view, the questionnaire content includes gender stereotypes on appearance, personality, career choice and function distribution in the family for males and females. The study found that some of the gender stereotyping tendencies of the participants were related to the participants’ own gender, while the binary gender stereotypes on family duties and responsibilities influenced each other. The findings revealed that participants who had stereotyped biases about the roles of men and women in the household influenced their perceptions of the responsibilities of the opposite gender. According to Google Academic Index, since 2018, a total of 16,900 articles on gender stereotypes and primary education have been retrieved in English, including academic journals, dissertations, conferences, newspapers, books and so on [1]. According to CNKI search, there were only 42 Chinese articles with double keywords since 2018 [2]. In this article, the author used questionnaires to investigate current students in Jinxiu Primary School in Henan Province, China. Results in this study confirm that gender stereotypes exist in elementary school students. The purpose is to better assist the education of students in early adolescence by raising awareness of gender education among teachers and students in local schools and giving suggestions. The subjects of the survey are grade five and six primary school students, most of whom are 11-12 years old. Fifth and sixth-grade students' self-consciousness has been formed, and the ability of self-evaluation and self-education has been rapidly developed. In this order students often think about "what kind of person I am" and "what kind of person I should be"[3]. The researcher chose students in this developmental stage because students at this stage are at the beginning of puberty: they have a clear understanding of gender, and they are in a stage of physical and mental development. Adolescent students begin to develop self-consciousness. On the one hand, they want to get out of the role of obeying their parents' arrangements. On the other hand, they cannot get rid of their parents’ control completely for adolescents still need their parents to support their studies and life. In terms of acceptance of knowledge and school life, it has changed from passive listening to self-awareness and selective acceptance. Therefore, primary school students at this stage are great research assets. The research focuses on three exposed traits in the impression of gender engraving, which are participants' personality, temperament, career choice and appearance. The research targets are Grade 5 and 6 students in Jinxiu Primary School, Zhanhe District, Pingdingshan City, Henan Province, China. The conclusion of this study can promote gender education in schools and strengthen teachers’ and students' understanding of the importance of gender education. Efforts have been made to promote and develop local emphases on gender education. The concept of stereotype first appeared in Walter's "Public Opinion". Walter believed that stereotype is a kind of inherent idea about a certain group or related events formed on the basis of race, gender and other conditions [4]. Hilton and Hippel believed that stereotype is a series of characteristics related to members of a social group, including personality, attitude, behavioral tendency and so on [4]. In the same year, Nelson et al. proposed a similar definition, arguing that stereotypes are cognitive constructs that contain knowledge, beliefs, and expectations about social groups, and that those who subscribe to negative stereotypes are prejudgments [5]. Jussim et al. believe that stereotype is the cognitive bias of people toward different groups, including four attributes: unconsciousness, inaccuracy, permanence, and over-generalization [6]. Domestic studies on stereotypes are mostly defined from the perspective of cognitive bias. With the refinement of scholars' research on stereotypes, different scholars divided the types of stereotypes according to the deviation of research direction. This article will focus only on gender role stereotypes.

Gender role stereotype refers to the public's expectations and requirements for males or females in behavior performance, personality characteristics, career choice and other aspects in today's society, as results in this study confirm that all as the fixed concept of this general view [7]. According to research, gender role stereotyping is a universal and global situation [7]. With the deepening of research, different researchers have put forward different definitions of gender role stereotyping. All port believes that gender stereotype is a mindset related to social concepts and is uncontrollable [7]. Both male and female individuals tend to choose the least cognitive processing when they perceive and judge things, and this way will affect thinking. As for the causes of gender stereotypes, one view is that it is caused by the different physiological characteristics of men and women [8]. The second view on the causes of gender stereotypes is that gender stereotypes are caused by the different occupations and positions of men and women in the family and society. All the studies on gender differences are considered as factors that affect gender differences in society environment and cultural factors play a decisive role, while human nature and physiological factors have little or no effect [9]. Chinese scholars have also come up with different ideas about gender role stereotypes. Researcher Xu Dazhen believed that the concept of gender stereotype refers to the fixed views on a male or female's social gender, behavior style, personality characteristics and other aspects that can be accepted and recognized in the familiar social culture [9]. In the same cultural background, this idea will be closer and more unified. For example, men are more masculine, brave and confident, while women are more delicate, vulnerable and sensitive. Results in this study confirm that gender stereotypes do exist and influence the growth of the next generation. This kind of thinking successively and subtly influence people's thoughts. In this study it confirms that with recognition, family and school can implement intervention and help children be more open-minded, rather than sticking to traditional gender beliefs. In this way, children can also have more choices in their future career and growth direction. Educators in this study should lead students more. Teachers can organize some gender topics through schools and discuss topics in class, including introducing some picture books with relevant themes consciously, so that gender issues will no longer be an unmentionable topic. Pre-service educators at their undergraduate stage should actively understand the knowledge of gender, not face it negatively, not be shy when facing the gender issue, and accept the development of diversity. At the same time, in the face of society's rigid view of their gender, students should be brave to say no, and establish their values and dialectical ideas. The popularization of gender education is beneficial to the physical and mental development of children. One of the early studies in the field found that even by only briefly presenting children with picture books involving nontraditional sex role models, their stereotypical ideas about gender role models could be reduced [10]. A different study with elementary school children showed that children who read stories with female main characters in non- traditional roles were more likely to believe that girls can engage in that particular non-traditional roles than children who had read the same story with a male main character [11]. Similar results were reported by Trepanier-Street and Romatowski [11]. After their reading intervention, more boys and girls viewed occupations as appropriate for both males and females. According to the researchers, the change in gender attitude of the children “seemed to generalize beyond the occupational roles portrayed in the books read in the study”, which even further underlines the significant impact books, as well as other cultural products children are daily faced with may have on children’s ideas about gender roles [10,12]. Through the experiment, it can show that human intervention will have an impact on children in primary school. Therefore, it can also show that if the intervention is carried out on school-age students in the fifth and sixth grade of primary school or even at an earlier stage, it may also have a bias to get rid of the influence of gender stereotypes.
